hints.Force: any interaction that, when unopposed, changes the motion of an object
hints.Motion: The change in an object's position over time.
hints.Speed: The distance traveled by an object per unit of time.
hints.Velocity: The speed of an object in a specific direction.
hints.Acceleration: The rate at which an object's velocity changes over time.
hints.Newton's Laws of Motion: Three fundamental laws that describe the relationship between the motion of an object and the forces acting on it.
hints.Gravity: The force of attraction between any two masses, like the Earth pulling objects toward its center.
hints.Friction: The force that opposes the motion of an object when it is in contact with another object or surface.
hints.Mass: The amount of matter in an object, which is related to its weight.
hints.Weight: The force exerted on an object due to gravity.
hints.Energy: The capacity to do work or cause change, which can be converted from one form to another.
hints.Potential energy: The stored energy an object has due to its position or condition.
hints.Kinetic energy: The energy an object has due to its motion.
hints.Work: The transfer of energy when a force moves an object over a distance.
hints.Power: The rate at which work is done, or energy is transferred.
hints.Simple machines: Basic mechanical devices that make work easier, such as levers, pulleys, and inclined planes.
hints.Waves: Disturbances that transfer energy from one point to another, like sound waves or water waves.
hints.Light: A form of electromagnetic radiation that allows us to see and is responsible for the colors we perceive.
hints.Reflection: The bouncing of light waves off a surface, like a mirror.
hints.Refraction: The bending of light waves as they pass from one medium to another, like when light passes through water or a lens.
hints.Centripetal force: force that acts on an object moving in a circular path, directed toward the center of the circle
hints.Conduction: transfer of heat through a material without the movement of the material itself
hints.Convection: transfer of heat by the movement of a fluid, such as air or water
hints.Radiation: transfer of energy through space in the form of electromagnetic waves
hints.Mechanical advantage: ratio of the force produced by a machine to the force applied to it
hints.Fluid dynamics: study of the motion and behavior of fluids, like liquids and gases
hints.Air resistance: force that opposes the motion of an object through the air
hints.Terminal velocity: maximum constant speed an object can reach while falling through a fluid, like air
hints.Fluid pressure: force exerted by a fluid on an object submerged in it
hints.Bernoulli's principle: principle stating that as the speed of a fluid increases, its pressure decreases
hints.Pascal's principle: principle stating that a change in pressure at any point in an enclosed fluid is transmitted equally to all parts of the fluid
hints.Archimedes' principle: principle stating that the buoyant force on an object submerged in a fluid is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object
